trans-unit.target: Welcome to WHAAM application. We have activated your account!
Has a special needs support teacher
Has an Individual Education Plan or Behaviour PLan
The ADHD diagnosis is secondary to other medical conditions
The new password has been created successfully and sent you via email. Please check your mailbox
This project has been funded with support from the European Commission.
This publication [communication] reflects the views only of the author, and the Commission
cannot be held responsible for any use which may be made of the information contained therein.
The aim of the WHAAM applications is to help you to identify and manage the difficult behaviours of children with ADHD. Click on the next button to view the application features
The toolbar allows you to do the following actions:
view the notifications about the actions done by other users in the network
The \'breadcrumbs\' help you to know where you are in the application. Click on each element to move quickly between the different pages.
Click here to add a new child and start to take advantage of the WHAAM application features.
A summary of the child\'s data is shown here. Click the next button to see additional actions.
The children\'s toolbar allows you to:
Click here to access a page where personal, medical, and school information about the child is held.
Click here to access the page where the unwanted ADHD behaviours are listed.
Click here to view the list of people in the child\'s private social network.
Click here to invite new people to join the child\'s private social network.
This page contains the unwanted behaviours of the child added by members of the virtual network. Click on the new button to add a new behaviour!
Click here to view the previous assessments. In the WHAAM application an assessment is a process to observe a behaviour, identify its function, and plan an intervention.
Strategies have not yet been inserted
The child and the related data will be permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. Are you sure you want to proceed?
The child's behaviour and the related assessments will be permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. Are you sure you want to proceed?
The behaviour function and the related assessments will be permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. Are you sure you want to proceed?
The intervention and the related observation data will be permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. Are you sure you want to proceed?
The baseline and the following phases including the relative data will be permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. Are you sure you want to proceed?
What personal information do I need to insert?

"The WHAAM application is aimed at supporting effective behavioural interventions in ADHD children by paying careful attention on the safety of the data. If you dont't like the idea of using the child’s real name or data, please do not hesitate to use just a nickname, sex and year of birth. The name and surname of child are an optional fields. For our part the safety of personal data is backed by the use of authenticated credential management procedures and the use of encryption techniques."
Who are people able to access personal information?
The child personal information is shared just with the agreed people involved in the child's private social network. Other people are not allowed to access it!
This page collects important information about the child and is organised in 5 areas:

The visible areas you can access are shown according to your personal role. For example, the most sensitive clinical information can only be seen by health professionals and the child\'s named relatives

These fields show a brief summary of the case information, including: some of the child\'s personal information,the onset age and the subtype of the disorder, school information, and the number of people involved in the child\'s private social network.

Please specify when the diagnosis was given, the age of onset and the subtype of the ADHD disorder. In addition you may optionally specify if the ADHD is a secondary condition and the main comorbidity.
What kind of data do I have to insert?
Oops! Looks like you followed a bad link. The resource you are looking for could have been removed, had its name changed, or is temporarily unavailable.
The server has encountered an internal error. If the problem persists, please contact the WHAAM staff by following the 'contact us' link.
It is important to keep track of the diagnoses because over time ADHD symptoms can change and may vary with the child's age and development stage.
Who is able to access the diagnosis data?
Diagnoses data is only by accessible the child's identified relatives and the health professionals directly involved in the child's private social network.
How do I define a behaviour?
To describe a behaviour is necessary to provide an operational definition: objective, concise and complete.

The behaviour is specifically described in a way that the reader is not require to guess what it means. Good examples are: "John stares out of the window", or “John hits a nearby pupil on the head with an open palm", or "John leaves his assigned seat without permission, during the English lesson". Unhelpful examples are: "John is behaving badly", or "John is violent", or "John wanders around".
Use short sentences to describe only what you have observed

A complete definition include the place and the setting in which the behaviour occurs. Example of place could be: "classroom", "playground", "kitchen". Example of setting could be..."During a transition time?". Or "In a Maths class on Monday morning". Fill in this field describing when the behaviour is more likely to occur.

A good setting description answers the question: "What was happening when the behaviour was observed?". Examples could be..."During a transition time?". Or "In a Maths class on Monday morning". Fill in this field describing when the behaviour is more likely to occur.
Send the notification about the baseline to the network members
If you confirm, the members of the child network will receive a notification about the baseline. It will no longer be allowed to make changes to the baseline settings.
Send the notification about the behaviour hypothesized function to the network members
If you confirm, the members of the child network will receive a notification about the behaviour function that you hypothesized. It will no longer be modifiable.
Send the notification about the intervention to the network members
If you confirm, the members of the child network will receive a notification about the intervention. It will be no longer allowed to make changes to the intervention settings
To set a New intervention, please select the start and the end date; this represent the period in which some actions, or strategies, will be applied

The intervention strategies are the actions applied to reduce or eliminate the behaviour. To add a strategy, please provide its Name, a clear Description and Assign it to one or more network components displayed

Description: a token (i.e. a coin, a sticker, etc.) is an object that is given to a child every time he exhibits an appropriate behavior. After having gained a predetermined number of tokens, the child can exchange them for material reinforcers (i.e. sweets, toys, interactive activities, etc.). A token-based system requires three base elements: 1) objects that are small and quantifiable 2) a reinforcer with which exchange them and 3) a behaviour defined in a clear way.
- Assign to: select one or more network components who will apply the strategy

Medications can play an important role in the life of an ADHD child. Knowing what medication is taken and its relative dosage is crucial for the health professional to better understand its effect on symptoms and behaviours of the child.
Who is able to access medication data?
Medication data are accessible only by child relatives and health professionals involved in the child network.
What these information are useful for?
Often ADHD pupils struggle to respect shared rules, so it's important to obtain information about their self-regulation skills and the consequences linked to off-task behaviours.
Who will access discipline referrals data?
Everyone involved in the child's virtual network.

These information are useful to obtain a more clear school situation of child. School year, school name and grade represent the actual scholastic level of child. The presence of the Individual Education Plan (IEP) describes the special education and related services specifically designed to meet the needs of a child with special educational needs. The IEP and the presence of a support teacher are crucial resources for designing a better intervention on the child.
Who is able to access school data?

During the lifetime new stressful events could happen increasing the risk for symptoms of other psychiatric disorders. Keeping track of them is important to understand their influence on the child behaviour. Please, select the date in which the New event occurred and provide to describe it clearly.
Who is able to access these information?

As in the most popular social networks like Facebook, Google+, or Linkedin, you can create a virtual network composed of people who are relevant for the ADHD child. You have just to ask them to join you via email filling in the invitation form.
What other people in the network can do?
They can share knowledge and relevant information about the child behaviors between themselves in order to work efficiently together.
If you have further problems, please contact abuses@whaam.pa.itd.cnr.it

The Baseline is the current level that a behaviour occurs prior to intervention. In the WHAAM application, during the baseline period, people involved in the child network will be allowed to gather data about the behaviour. Select an observer, specify the number of observation sessions and the lenght in minutes of each observation. Please, remember that to have access to the evaluation area of the intervention, the system requires minimum 4 observation sessions.

Please fill this field with a brief description of the discipline referral selected. e.g. If the option selected is "Time-out" specify the motivation of this referral, who has proposed it and in which circumstances it happened. Do the same for the option "Other".
What baseline data are useful for?
Baseline data are used to hypothesize the function of a behaviour and to plan an intervention.

The data collected through the systematic observation are processed differently according to the choice: frequency or duration. In the former case data will be processed counting the behaviour occurrence. In the latter the WHAAM application processes data counting percent of time that a behaviour occurs during the observation period.
Data are collected using the WHAAM mobile app directly on your mobile phone or tablet.
The section Edit user allow you to update the information about the user profile.
This section allow you to change the password. You have to insert the previous password in order to define the new password
How to identify the behaviour function?

The behaviour function describes "why" the behaviour occurs. You have to fill in the field "When" to describe the specific social, affective, cognitive, and/or enviromentals events in relationship with the occurrence of behaviour.
What are the possible behaviour function?

It is often helpful to think, “What purpose is this behaviour serving the child?” when you have to identify the behaviour function. You can find one of the following four functions as purpose of behaviour:
Escape or avoidance: the child engages in the behaviour to escape aversive socially mediated attention.
Obtain a tangible item or gain access to a desired activity

The purpose of the behaviour is focused to obtain a specific item or engage in a specific activity from another person. For example, a child hits mom because s/he wants the toy mom is holding. (If this behaviour results in mom giving the child the toy, s/he will be more likely to engage in the same behaviour in the future to get mom's attention.) Common forms of tangible items include, but are not limited to, food, toys, movies, video games, etc.

The individual engages in the behaviour because the response-produced stimulation possesses reinforcing characteristics. For example, a child spinning a bowl on a table to produce the specific auditory stimulation unique to that object.
The child engages in the behaviour to get attention from another person. For example, a child throws a toy for gaining the mom's attention.
What is the porpouse of the Note field?
You can use the Note field to add any further useful information.
Escape/Removal of Tasks or Activities: The child engages in the behaviour to escape difficult tasks or demands.
I have a parental consent or equivalent authorization to access data and invite new people to join the child network.
Why I have to specify my role?

The role in the child virtual network is crucial to attribute the right privileges to the logged user. In particular, health professionals and parents of the child have higher privileges than other profiles. Health professionals are enabled to plan behavioural intervention plans based on the data gathered by the child virtual network. Parents can manage the participation of users in the network, inviting people with whom they like to share personal information
Is the role specified here global in the WHAAM application?
No. The role is contextual to the child for whom you are working. For instance, you could be an health professional for a child and a grandfather for another one.
Can I invite someone else if I have not a parental consent or equivalent?

Yes, you can invite new people to join the child network. If you are the person who inserted the child record, you take the responsability to share the child data with new people. Otherwise the invitation will be moderated by the person who has inserted the child for the first time in the WHAAM system.
You are removing a person from the child network.
this feature should be used just in case of abuses or if someone involved in the network a person with whom you don't want to share data.
If you have further problems, please contact abuses@whaam.pa.itd.cnr.it
The selected record will be permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. Are you sure you want to proceed?
Attention: The time distance between sessions should be regular as more as possible.
You have to gather at least 4 observations for both the baseline and the treatment phases to have access to the evaluation of the data efficacy.
You can not find the behaviour in the list?
Check the box and write it!
Cancel and go back to the behaviours' list
This page is aimed to plan the behavioural intervention and to evaluate the data gathered by the virtual network of the child.
This means that the first step is gathering information about the baseline of the behaviour, then the HP will be able to hypothesize which function is supporting it
and plan a behavioural intervention to reduce or eliminate the target behaviour.
Finally, the gathered data will be evaluated in order to check if the treatment has had the expected effect on the behaviour.
These buttons are displayed green if you can add the relative phase or gray if you can\'t.
Please remember that the assessment phases have to be inserted in a row as follow: baseline, function, intervention.
The evalution will be automatically calculated when at least 4 observation sessions for both baseline and intervention will be gathered.
The phase toolbar allows you to
send notifications to the other members network about the phase you defined. Since modification are sent
the phase settings modification will be restricted.
Other information about the assessment phase are accessible clicking on the relative icon. The baseline phase allows users to access ABCs data and visualize observation charts.
The child's behaviour assessment and the related observation sessions will be permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. Are you sure you want to proceed?
What happens right before the behaviour occurs?
What happened after or as a result of the child’s behavior?
How has the child's behaviour changed as a result of the described consequences?
